snippet: All major suspects of the Bali bombings in 2002 have been killed or jailed, with their group crippled by anti-terrorism operations. But some militants have moved to form new cells and seek new recruits.
abstract: Analysts say that while Indonesian counterterrorism forces have managed to cripple Jemaah Islamiyah, Southeast Asian offshoot of Al Qaeda, some disaffected individuals and members of vigilante groups have moved to form new cells and seek new recruits.
lead_paragraph: All major suspects of the Bali bombings in 2002 have been killed or jailed, with their group crippled by anti-terrorism operations. But some militants have moved to form new cells and seek new recruits.

headline.main: 10 Years After Bali Bombings, Local Militants Still Pose Threat
headline.print_headline:
Indonesia Seeing Increase
Of Small Terrorist Groups
